column1: 10:00|"10:00 A.M."|"Just to mention an example of hygiene and disease that impressed me personally
column2: on a trip to Indonesia during which I spent most of each day bird-watching alone on forest trails radiating from a campsite shared with Indonesian colleagues
column3: I was disconcerted to discover that I was experiencing sudden attacks of diarrhea at an hour varying unpredictably from day to day. I racked my brain to figure out what I was doing wrong
column4: and what could account for the variation of the attacks’ timing. Finally
column5: I made the connection. Each day
column6: a wonderfully kind Indonesian colleague
column7: who felt responsible for my well-being
column8: came out from camp and followed my trail of that day until he encountered me
column9: to make sure that I hadn’t had an accident or gotten lost. He handed me some biscuits that he had thoughtfully brought from camp as a snack
column10: chatted with me for a few minutes to satisfy himself that all was well with me
column11: and returned to camp. One evening
column12: I suddenly realized that my diarrhea attack each day began about half an hour after my kind friend had met me and I had eaten his biscuits on that day: if he met me at 10:00 A.M.
column14: and if he met me at 2:30 P.M.
column15: it came at 3:00 P.M. From the next day onwards
column16: I thanked him for his biscuits
column17: disposed of them inconspicuously after he had turned back
column18: and never had any more attacks. The problem had originated with my friend’s handling of the biscuits rather than with the biscuits themselves
column19: of which we kept a supply in their original cellophane packets at our camp
column20: and which never made me ill when I opened the packet myself. Instead
column21: the cause of the attacks must have been intestinal pathogens transmitted from my friend’s fingers to the biscuits."|"The World Until Yesterday"|"Jared Diamond"

column1: ap ~ 02:50|"about 250"|"Aboriginal Australia was occupied by about 250 different language groups
column2: all of them subsisting by hunting-gathering
column3: with an average of about a thousand speakers per language. All reliable reports describe most traditional Aboriginals as being at least bilingual
column4: and most as knowing many languages. One such study was carried out by anthropologist Peter Sutton in the Cape Keerweer area of the Cape York Peninsula
column5: where the local population of 683 people was divided into 21 clans
column6: each with a different form of speech and averaging 33 people per clan. Those speech forms are classified into five languages plus about seven dialects
column7: so that the average number of speakers is about 53 per speech form
column8: or 140 per language. Traditional Aborigines in the area spoke or understood at least five different languages or dialects. In part because speech communities are so tiny
column9: and in part because of a preference for linguistic exogamy (marrying someone whose primary language is not one’s own)
column10: 60% of marriages are between partners speaking different languages
column11: another 16% are between speakers of different dialects of the same language
column12: and only 24% are within the same dialect. That is despite the fact that neighboring clans tend to be linguistically similar
column13: so that mere propinquity would lead to marriages being made within the same dialect if it were not for that preference for seeking geographically and linguistically more remote partners."|"The World Until Yesterday"|"Jared Diamond"
